data.title: Oil Set for Third Monthly Drop
data.description:
WTI crude oil futures fell toward $60 per barrel on Friday, heading for a third straight monthly decline, pressured by rising global output ahead of the OPEC+ meeting.

The cartel is inclined to raise production by 137,000 barrels per day in December as part of its strategy to regain market share.

This adds to an already well-supplied market, with Saudi Arabia’s crude exports rising to a six-month high of 6.41 million bpd in August and further gains expected, while the EIA reported record US output of 13.6 million bpd last week.

These developments could help offset the impact of recent US sanctions on major Russian oil producers, with investors watching how the measures will affect exports to key buyers.

Meanwhile, President Trump said China has agreed to resume purchases of US energy, including a potential large oil and gas deal from Alaska.

Elsewhere, a stronger greenback weighed on commodities.

Brent Set for Third Monthly Drop
data.description:
Brent crude oil futures fell to around $64 per barrel on Friday, heading for a third straight monthly decline, pressured by rising global output ahead of the OPEC+ meeting.

The cartel is inclined to raise production by 137,000 barrels per day in December as part of its strategy to regain market share.

This adds to an already well-supplied market, with Saudi Arabia’s crude exports rising to a six-month high of 6.41 million bpd in August and further gains expected, while the EIA reported record US output of 13.6 million bpd last week.

These developments could help offset the impact of recent US sanctions on major Russian oil producers, with investors watching how the measures will affect exports to key buyers.

Meanwhile, President Trump said China has agreed to resume purchases of US energy, including a potential large oil and gas deal from Alaska.

Elsewhere, a stronger greenback weighed on commodities.

China's factory activity shrinks for seventh month in October, PMI shows
data.description:
China's factory activity shrank for a seventh month in October, an official survey showed on Friday, suggesting the need for further stimulus to boost demand, with efforts to ship goods abroad merely exporting price wars.

The official purchasing managers' index (PMI) dropped to 49.0 in October, a 6-month low, versus 49.8 in September, below the 50-mark separating growth from contraction, and missing a median forecast of 49.6 in a Reuters poll.

data.title: China Services PMI Remains Near 10-Month Low
data.description: China’s official NBS Non-Manufacturing PMI stood at 50.1 in October 2025, barely changed from September’s 10-month low of 50.0.

data.title: China non-manufacturing activity expands in September, PMI shows
data.description:
China's non-manufacturing activity returned to expansion in October, an official survey showed on Friday.

The non-manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI), which includes services and construction, rose to 50.1 from 50.0 in September, according to the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS).

The NBS composite PMI of manufacturing and non-manufacturing fell to 50.0 in October, compared with 50.6 in September.

The 50-point mark separates expansion from contraction in activity on a monthly basis.

Midland States Bancorp Inc reports results for the quarter ended September 30 - Earnings Summary
data.description:
• Midland States Bancorp Inc reported quarterly adjusted earnings of 24 cents​​ per share for the quarter ended September 30, lower than the same quarter last year, when the company reported EPS of 74 cents. The mean expectation of five analysts for the quarter was for earnings of 64 cents per share. Wall Street expected results to range from 56 cents to 74 cents per share.

  • Revenue rose 9.2% to $81.13 million from a year ago; analysts expected $79.04 million.

  • Midland States Bancorp Inc's reported EPS for the quarter was 24 cents​.

  • The company reported quarterly net income of $5.33 million.

  • Midland States Bancorp Inc shares had fallen by 5.7% this quarter and lost 33.8% so far this year.

FORECAST CHANGES

  • The mean earnings estimate of analysts had risen by about 4.2% in the last three months.​

  • In the last 30 days, there have been no earnings estimate revisions by analysts covering the company.

RECOMMENDATIONS

  • The current average analyst rating on the shares is "hold" and the breakdown of recommendations is no "strong buy" or "buy," 5 "hold" and no "sell" or "strong sell." The average consensus recommendation for the banks peer group is "buy."

  • Wall Street's median 12-month price target for Midland States Bancorp Inc is $20.50, about 21.9% above its last closing price of $16.02

This summary was machine generated from LSEG data October 31 at 01:30 a.m. UTC. ​All figures in US dollars unless otherwise stated. data.title: Midland States Bancorp's Q3 net income drops sharply; exits equipment finance business
data.description:
Overview

  • Midland States Bancorp Q3 net income falls to $5.3 mln, or $0.24 per share, from $18.2 mln, or $0.83 per share, last year

  • Company ceased equipment finance production to reduce risk exposure

  • Net interest margin rises to 3.79% from 3.56% in the prior quarter

Outlook

  • Midland States Bancorp expects common equity tier 1 capital ratio to reach the 10% target, as it improved to 9.4% in the quarter

  • Companystopped all new originations in its equipment finance portfolio to reduce exposure to higher-risk assets

  • Midland States Bancorp anticipates a positive impact on net interest margin from the reduction of higher-cost deposits

Result Drivers

  • EQUIPMENT FINANCE PROVISION - $15 mln provision in equipment finance portfolio due to increased loss assumptions

  • NONPERFORMING ASSETS - Decreased to $70 mln, or 1.02% of total assets, from 2.10% at the end of 2024, reflecting efforts to reduce problem loans

  • NET INTEREST MARGIN - Increased to 3.79% QoQ due to lower funding costs and interest recovery

Key Details

Metric

Q3 EPS

Beat/Miss

Actual

$0.24

Consensus Estimate

Analyst Coverage

  • The current average analyst rating on the shares is "hold" and the breakdown of recommendations is no "strong buy" or "buy", 5 "hold" and no "sell" or "strong sell"

  • The average consensus recommendation for the banks peer group is "buy"

  • Wall Street's median 12-month price target for Midland States Bancorp Inc is $20.50, about 21.9% above its October 30 closing price of $16.02

data.title: Gold rises on bargain hunting and US rate cut, set for monthly gain
data.description:
Gold prices edged higher on Friday, and were on track for a third straight monthly gain, as bargain hunting and a Federal Reserve interest rate cut lifted demand, while investors digested a tentative trade deal between China and the U.S.

FUNDAMENTALS

* Spot gold was up 0.3% at $4,034 per ounce, as of 0109 GMT. Bullion has gained 4.5% so far this month.

* U.S. gold futures for December delivery slipped 1.1% to $3,955 per ounce.

* On Wednesday, the U.S. central bank cut interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point for the second time this year, taking the benchmark overnight rate to a target range of 3.75%–4.00%.

* Non-yielding gold thrives in a low interest rate environment and during economic uncertainties.

* Traders have scaled back bets that the Fed will cut rates again at its next policy meeting on December 10 after remarks from Fed Chair Jerome Powell.

* Markets are now pricing in a 74.8% probability of a 25-basis-point cut from the Fed in December compared with a 91.1% chance a week ago, according to the CME Group's FedWatch tool.

* Keeping gold's gains in check, the dollar index held near its highest level in three months against its rivals, making bullion more expensive for other currency holders.

* U.S. President Donald Trump said on Thursday he had agreed with Chinese President Xi Jinping to trim tariffs on China in exchange for Beijing cracking down on the illicit fentanyl trade, resuming U.S. soybean purchases and keeping rare earths exports flowing.

* Global gold demand rose 3% year-on-year to 1,313 metric tons, the highest quarterly number on record, in the third quarter as investment demand soared, the World Gold Council said on Thursday.

* Meanwhile, SPDR Gold Trust , the world's largest gold-backed exchange-traded fund, said its holdings rose 0.42% to 1,040.35 tons on Thursday from 1,036.05 tons on Wednesday.

* Elsewhere, spot silver was steady at $48.92 per ounce, platinum rose 0.2% to $1,613.50 and palladium climbed 2.1% to $1,474.5174.

data.description: China’s NBS Composite PMI Output Index slipped to 50.0 in October 2025 from 50.6 in the previous month, marking the lowest reading since December 2022.

data.title: China Manufacturing Contracts More Than Expected
data.description:
China’s official NBS Manufacturing PMI declined to 49.0 in October 2025, down from 49.8 in the prior month and below market forecasts of 49.6.

While factory activity contracted for the seventh consecutive month, the pace of decline was the slowest in the sequence, highlighting the need for further stimulus to boost domestic consumption.

data.title: Saylor’s Strategy boosts after hours as firm posts $2.8B Q3 income
data.description:
Shares in Strategy have risen nearly 6% after hours as the Bitcoin treasury company reported a net income of $2.8 billion for its third quarter, down from the second quarter but still beating analyst expectations.

Strategy on Thursday reported diluted earnings per share of $8.42 for the three months ending Sept. 30, beating Wall Street expectations of $8.15. 

Its $2.8 million income for the quarter was a major jump from its $340.2 million loss the same time a year ago, but a fall from its record $10 billion net income in Q2.

Shares in Strategy (MSTR) climbed 5.7% after-hours to over $269 after ending the trading session on Thursday down over 7.5% at an over six-month low of $254.57.

Strategy has the largest stockpile of Bitcoin (BTC) among public companies, and the cryptocurrency’s over 6.5% rise over the quarter helped to buoy the company’s income.

Bitcoin is down 1.7% in the past 24 hours, recovering to $108,500 from an intraday low of under $106,500.

The decline in the price of Bitcoin and Strategy’s stock has squeezed its mNAV to 1.05x, falling from a peak of 3.89x in November after Bitcoin rocketed on Donald Trump’s US election win, according to StrategyTracker data. 

Strategy said its Bitcoin yield had hit 26% so far this year at a $13 billion gain and reaffirmed its full-year outlook of hitting a 30% Bitcoin yield with a net income of $24 billion, based on its estimation that Bitcoin will reach $150,000.

The company added 42,706 BTC over the third quarter to hold 640,031 BTC by Sept. 30. It has since continued its buys to hold 640,808 as of Sunday, which Strategy said was bought at an average cost of $74,032.

Viking Acquisition Corp. I Is a Blank Check Company >VACI.U
Viking Acquisition Corp. I Announces Pricing of $200,000,000 Initial Public Offering
Standard Chartered justifies shareholders’ caution
data.description:
By Antony Currie

Even Bill Winters wasn’t expecting to have it so good in the first half of the year. The Standard Chartered CEO went into 2025 with the goal of inching the $46 billion lender’s slowly improving return on tangible equity up to 13% by the end of 2026. In the six months to the end of June it rocketed to an annualised rate of 18.7%. If sustainable, that would warrant the bank trading at close to 2 times tangible book value, far above its current multiple. Shareholders, though, have paid more attention to Winters’ words than his deeds. StanChart’s third-quarter earnings released on Thursday justify their caution.

The bank’s net income came in at $1.3 billion, above consensus estimates but 25% lower than the bumper showing in the preceding three months. The one-quarter revenue drop in global markets accounted for much of that. But it’s hardly a disaster: diminishing trade tensions reduce volatility and thus clients’ desire to hedge, taking the top line back to a similar level as last year’s third quarter. Meanwhile there was other good news. Revenue in the wealth business, which Winters has earmarked for expansion, hit a record. Moreover Winters and finance chief Diego De Giorgi are keeping costs under control.

The robust performance comes after years of underperformance – and has done wonders for the stock. Standard Chartered shares are up 66% over the past 12 months and almost 130% since the start of 2024, outstripping rivals HSBC , DBS and Citigroup in both instances.

That, though, leaves it trading at around 1.2 times tangible book value, which is roughly in line with Winters’ returns target. That multiple would have started to look stingy if the bank had cranked out another stellar quarter. Instead, StanChart’s more even-paced performance means that, barring a major blow-up, Winters should easily hit his target early. He’s now forecasting a return of around 13% for 2025. Hitting that number on the nose requires earning just $250 million in the fourth quarter, Breakingviews calculates, which suggests Winters could well end up doing better. For now, shareholders will be breathing a sigh of relief that they have been following what Winters said, not what he did.

Follow Antony Currie on Bluesky and LinkedIn.

CONTEXT NEWS

Standard Chartered on October 30 reported third-quarter earnings of $1.3 billion, or 44.5 cents a share. That compares to the consensus estimate of sell-side analysts provided by the bank of 39 cents a share, per data collected by LSEG. Revenue for the period was $5.1 billion, compared to an estimated $5 billion. Return on tangible equity was 10.5% and 13.4% on an underlying earnings basis, which strips out one-off factors.

data.title: Shenzhen Composite Index Opens 0.1% Lower at 2516.08
Shanghai Composite Index Opens 0.05% Lower at 3985.06
China Vanke's Nine-Month Net Loss Widens as Sales Slow
data.description:
By Amanda Lee

China Vanke's net loss in the first nine months of the year widened as sales continued to fall amid the years-long downturn in the country's property sector.

The Chinese developer's net loss increased 56%, compared with the same period a year earlier, to 28.02 billion yuan, equivalent to $3.94 billion, in the three quarters ending September, it said late Thursday.

Revenue was CNY161.39 billion, down 27% on year, as contracted sales dropped 45% on year to CNY100.46 billion.

The latest results represented continued pressure on its operations, said China Vanke.

"With the strong support from all parties and major shareholder, the group made every effort to ensure the stability of the team, finance, production and operation, and the efforts of reform and risk mitigation advanced steadily," it added.

"However, from a future trend perspective, the Company's contract sales continue to decline, and the overall operating situation remains severe," it said.

It added that its faces intensifying tight liquidly and pressure to repay debts.

Write to Amanda Lee at amanda.lee@wsj.com
